Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Summer Neuroscience Undergraduate Research Fellowship Program at UVM
Award.AbstractNarration:
This REU Site award to the University of Vermont (UVM), located in Burlington, VT, will support the training of 8 undergraduate students for 10 weeks during the summers of 2016-2018. The theme of the REU program is neuroscience. Students will be mentored by faculty participating in UVM's PhD-granting Neuroscience Graduate Program (NGP) and will conduct research aimed at elucidating the anatomical, cellular, molecular, and behavioral aspects of neurobiology. Students will have access to NGP resources, including up-to-date imaging and molecular facilities. Students can select from a range of innovative projects that combine the behavioral analysis of genetically altered model organisms with high resolution imaging of the nervous system. Students will be trained in a wide range of scientific methodologies that include biochemical analysis, DNA sequencing and gene expression analysis, quantitative morphology, and behavioral analysis. Particular emphasis is placed on the teaching of valid experimental design, statistical analysis and interpretation. Weekly lectures are designed to highlight seminal experimental studies and studies that have established the basic concepts of modern neuroscience. Other lectures are focused on issues of career development and the importance of ethical and responsible scientific conduct. The end products of the program include student-authored posters that are presented to the entire UVM community at a poster session. Students are encouraged to take the posters to their home institution and further scientific meetings for additional presentations.

It is anticipated that a total of 24 students, many from schools with limited research opportunities, will be trained in the program. A diverse cohort of students that includes minority students underrepresented in STEM as well as underserved students from diverse social backgrounds and geographical origin will be actively recruited. Selection of applicants is based primarily on the applicant's interest in neuroscience and the potential that the program can enhance the applicant's career, rather than just academic scores. Application is available online at www.uvm.edu/~nbhspire/?Page=snurf.html.

A common web-based assessment tool, used by all REU programs funded by the Division of Biological Infrastructure (Directorate for Biological Sciences), will be used to determine the effectiveness of the training program. The results will be used to guide continued program improvement. Students will be tracked after the program in order to determine their career paths. Students will be asked to respond to an automatic email sent via the NSF reporting system. More information about the program is available online at http://www.uvm.edu/~nbhspire/?Page-snurf.html (PI Dr. Felix Eckenstein) or by contacting Mr. Daniel Mills (802-656-0435, Daniel.Mills@uvm.edu)

POR.DRECONTENT:
The summer neuroscience undergraduate research (REU) program at the University of Vermont (UVM) brought undergraduates from across the country for ten weeks to train and conduct research with a diverse selection of neuroscience faculty investigators. The program spanned four summers (2016-2019). Faculty expertise and student research covered multiple levels of neurobiological organization including biochemical, cellular, genetic, physiological, psychological, computational, behavioral and developmental.

The goals and outcomes of the project were as follows:

Goal 1.To provide at least 24 undergraduate students a hands-on neuroscience research experience with a strong faculty mentor. The selection process was to enhance participation of a diverse set of applicants, including underrepresented students and first-generation college students.

Outcome: Over the course of the program, 28 students were funded and conducted research at UVM. Student representation was diverse. Students self-identified with the following demographic characteristics: 71% women, 29% men, 32% from underrepresented minority groups (Latino/African American/Native American), and 21% as first-generation college students. Each student worked with a strong research/professional mentor and conducted high-level neuroscience research. Students joined the program from across the country with representation from the following states (and Puerto Rico): CT, DE, GA, IL, ME, MD (2), MA (4), MO, NH, NJ, NY, NC, PN (2), PR (3), SC, TX, VT (4), WA.

Goal 2. Conduct weekly mentorship and social meetings consisting of both student and faculty presentations on topics in neuroscience, ethics, safety, professional development skills, career opportunities, and opportunities for community building.

Outcome: All students participated in weekly training and mentorship meetings run by knowledgeable and experienced faculty. Students were trained in all of the areas listed under the goal. Social meetings were coordinated by UVM graduate students, by faculty members, and by the REU students. A strong community was established. Many students remain good friends and continue to maintain a strong relationship with PIs and faculty mentors.

Goal 3: Provide a research forum for student poster presentations attended by the neuroscience community at UVM.

Outcome: Students were trained in the preparation and presentation (orally and written) of scientific studies and results. Each student prepared and presented a professional scientific poster to the neuroscience community at UVM. Most of these students presented their posters at their academic institutions upon return and seven presented their research at regional or national scientific conferences. Five peer-reviewed research articles were published in major scientific journals featuring work from REU students. Further, it is anticipated that many of the results generated by the participants will be featured in future articles.

Goal 4: Assess how students are achieving their goals through student surveys and by tracking outcomes of participating students.

Outcome: At the end of each summer, REU students participated anonymously in a survey that assessed the REU program as well as provided information about how the program influenced their professional goals. This enabled program directors the ability to learn from a cohort and improve the program for the next year. Further, students provided contact information so that the directors could communicate with them and assess their professional progress. Students from the program are currently engaged in the following: Ph.D. programs (25%), undergraduate programs (14%), research assistant/technician positions (36%), other, including the Peace Corps and AmeriCorps (25%).

In summary, 28 REU students, with diverse representation, conducted neuroscience research with excellent mentors at UVM. Students were trained in science, ethics, safety, and the presentation of scientific studies and results. Students presented scientific posters to the UVM neuroscience community, at their home institutions and at regional/national scientific conferences. Five research articles were published and others are in preparation from research conducted by these REU students. REU student participants were well-trained and most continue to advance professionally in positions relevant to their training in this program.
